channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.

item.title: Signal amplification in a solid-state sensor through asymmetric many-body echo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09452-7

The experimental demonstration of many-body signal amplification in a solid-state, room-temperature quantum sensor is reported.
item.dc:title: Signal amplification in a solid-state sensor through asymmetric many-body echo
item.dc:creator: Haoyang Gao
Leigh S. Martin
Lillian B. Hughes
Nathaniel T. Leitao

item.title: Long-distance remote epitaxy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09484-z

Experimental evidence demonstrates long-distance remote epitaxial interactions of thin films even through thick amorphous carbon buffer layers and shows that these can be induced through dislocations in the substrate.
item.dc:title: Long-distance remote epitaxy

item.title: Spin squeezing in an ensemble of nitrogen–vacancy centres in diamond
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09524-8

An ensemble of spins from nitrogen–vacancy centres in diamonds is prepared in a spin-squeezed state.
item.dc:title: Spin squeezing in an ensemble of nitrogen–vacancy centres in diamond
item.dc:creator: Weijie Wu
Emily J. Davis

item.title: AI is dreaming up millions of new materials. Are they any good?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03147-9

Critics slammed attempts by Google, Microsoft and Meta to speed up materials discovery. But behind the hype, there is progress.
item.dc:title: AI is dreaming up millions of new materials. Are they any good?
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow

item.title: Quantum correlations enhance the sensitivity of room-temperature sensors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02968-y

Quantum sensors based on diamond promise robustness but have limited sensitivity. Generating quantum correlations in the material might be a solution.
item.dc:title: Quantum correlations enhance the sensitivity of room-temperature sensors
item.dc:creator: Maja S. Scharnagl
Klemens Hammerer
